awd_titl_txt: Theory and application of medium-term successional dynamics in secondary tropical forest
awd_abstract_narration:
There is a growing need to restore extensive areas of degraded habitat in tropical areas to forest in order to conserve biodiversity, mitigate the impacts of climate change (through carbon sequestration), reduce erosion and loss of topsoil, and provide for human livelihoods, yet little is known about how well tropical forest restoration strategies work beyond the first few years of establishment. This long-term experiment aims to address two key questions about tropical forest recovery.  First, the research compares natural forest recovery to two different forest restoration approaches (a low and high intensity approach) to assess how the degree of human intervention affects the rate of tropical forest recovery.  Second, the study evaluates the importance of the proximity of restored sites to remnant forest patches, which can serve as a source for colonizing plants and animals.  Results of this study will provide critical guidance to land managers and policy makers on how to most effectively invest limited resources to improve the outcomes of the millions of hectares of tropical forest restoration being undertaken globally. The study will provide training for graduate and undergraduate students, and new inquiry-based learning program will actively engage high school students in the research. 

Over a decade ago, 13 experimental sites were established over a 100 square kilometer area in southern Costa Rica, each site with a range of surrounding forest cover. Each site has three experimental treatments: 1. no tree planting and natural recovery; 2. planting tree islands of three sizes (low intensity); and 3. planting the entire plot with trees (high intensity). Researchers will collect data on metrics to assess the next phase of forest succession, including measuring soil nutrients, local microclimate, seed dispersal, tree growth, and the establishment and survival of forest seedlings.  In addition, plots will be used by collaborating scientists to study other facets of forest recovery such as insect community dynamics, and bird and bat behavior. The data will be used to address several questions about mid-stage forest recovery and how the pattern of recovery can change over time including: the effect of restoration interventions on within- and across-site biodiversity; the degree to which manipulations of initial conditions result in convergent or divergent successional trajectories from reference forest; and the relative importance of local- versus landscape-scale processes on forest recovery.

por.por_cntn:
There are multiple global commitments to restore hundreds of millions of hectares of tropical forest to conserve biodiversity, mitigate the impacts of climate change, reduce erosion and loss of topsoil, and provide for human livelihoods, yet there is little information on how well tropical forest restoration strategies work beyond the first few years of establishment. Our long-term (now 19 years old) experiment addresses two key questions about tropical forest recovery. First, the research compares natural (unassisted) forest recovery to two different forest restoration approaches to assess how the extent of active human intervention affects the rate of tropical forest recovery. Second, the study evaluates the importance of the proximity of restored sites to remnant forest patches, which can serve as a source for colonizing plants and animals. 

In 2004-2006, we established 15 experimental sites over a 100 km2 area in southern Costa Rica with a range of surrounding forest cover (Figure 1). Each site has three experimental treatments (Figure 2): 1. no tree planting/natural recovery; 2. planting tree islands of three sizes (applied nucleation); and 3. planting the entire plot with trees (plantation). Our study is now the longest continuously running restoration experiment that is replicated at multiple sites. With funding from this grant (2015-2023) we collected data on several metrics of forest recovery including vegetation structure and composition, seed dispersal, soil nutrients, soil and dead wood carbon storage, insects, and bird communities.

Our research provides a number of scientific and management insights. First, planting tree islands (applied nucleation) is as effective in restoring species composition of most guilds and ecosystem functions, as compared to the more resource intensive plantation style approach (Figure 3), and creates more heterogenous light conditions which favor sapling growth. Second, tree cover expanded rapidly beyond the planted area in the tree island (applied nucleation) treatment and by the end of the study was only slightly lower than in plantation plots (Figure 4); tree cover in the natural regeneration treatment was highly variable across sites and lower than the planted treatments. Third, our data demonstrate that the restored sites are recovering over time, particularly in the tree island and plantation treatments, but that the species composition still differs substantially from reference forest; full forest recovery will take more time. Finally, landscape analyses show that proximity to source populations of flora and fauna is important for forest recovery, but there are many sources of tree species in the agricultural landscape outside of forest remnants that can facilitate forest recovery. So, while it is important to conserve remnant forest patches, protecting isolated trees in agricultural landscapes is also critical. We published 22 scientific articles on this research during the grant period and wrote several blogs and general audience summaries. We also produced two 7-minute videos on the project (in English and Spanish), which have been viewed a total of >17,000 times.

Our research has had important broader impacts. The project PIs worked with Conservation International to develop a restoration guide for land managers and have advised restoration practitioners in multiple countries on forest restoration efforts. The project provided research and training for 2 postdoctoral fellows, 9 graduate students, ~10 undergraduate students from the U.S. (including two REU students), and several Costa Rican field technicians and students. We developed an online case study about our research for use in upper division undergraduate courses in tropical biology and restoration ecology; the case study has been translated into Spanish, Portuguese, and Bahasa Indonesia. Finally, project PIs and other team members have given numerous talks to scientific and general audiences in the U.S. and in several other countries.
